papers_dir: papers\Bundle-Size Pricing as an Approximation to Mixed Bundling - Chu et al. (2010).pdf

agentic.question: What is the key contribution?

sub_answers.question: ResponseTextConfig(format=ResponseFormatText(type='text'), verbosity='medium')
sub_answers.answer:
- What the context provides
  - A set of tables (C1, C3, C5) reporting profits relative to BSP under various pricing schemes and cost scenarios, across five “Taste” categories (K, UP, CP, PB, MB) and multiple distributions (Normal, Lognormal(+/-), Normal(v+/v-), etc.). C1 covers zero marginal costs; C3 covers positive but unequal marginal costs (0.5); C5 covers zero marginal costs with capacity constraints. Citations: Table C1 entries (page 7, words 0–178; continuation page 9, 0–178), Table C3 entries (page 17, 0–181; continuation page 19, 0–181), Table C5 entries (page 27, 0–181; continuation page 29, 0–181). 
  - The tables include explicit examples like Lognormal(+), Lognormal(-), Normal, Normal(v+), Normal(v-), and Normal(+/-) across different rows/scenarios.

- What to take away (high level)
  - Under zero marginal costs (Table C1), many profits cluster around 1.0 for several distributions/schemes, with some deviations (e.g., values like 0.771, 0.934, 0.999, 1.000; 0.650, 0.911, 0.999, 1.000 in early rows). See page 7 and page 9 excerpts. 
  - Under positive unequal marginal costs (0.5) (Table C3), profits show greater variation across distributions (e.g., Lognormal(+), Lognormal(-), Normal, Normal(v+/v-)), with several entries above and below 1.0 (e.g., 0.760, 0.958, 0.971, 1.000; Normal(v+) blocks; Normal(v-) blocks). See page 17 and page 19 excerpts.
  - With capacity constraints (Table C5), there are more pronounced fluctuations, including some values exceeding 1.1–1.2 in places (e.g., Lognormal(+/-) and Normal blocks), and other values below 0.6–0.7 depending on the scenario. See page 27 and page 29 excerpts.

- Representative numbers (illustrative)
  - Zero marginal costs (C1): examples include 0.771, 0.934, 0.999, 1.000; 0.650, 0.911, 0.999, 1.000; 0.707–0.976 blocks in Lognormal/Normal sections. See page 7 (and continuation on page 9).
  - Positive marginal costs (0.5) (C3): examples include 0.760, 0.958, 0.971, 1.000; 0.936, 0.984, 0.999, 1.022 in Lognormal(+); 0.814, 0.997, 0.998, 1.189 in Lognormal(-); Normal blocks around 0.968–1.093. See pages 17–19.
  - Capacity constraints (C5): examples include 0.698, 0.846, 0.877, 1.000; 0.816, 0.977, 1.000, 1.132 (Lognormal(-)); 1.143 in Normal block; values around 0.7–1.2 across the table. See pages 27–29.

- How to read (brief)
  - Tables list profits relative to BSP by scenario/taste and distribution, across several pricing schemes. Values near 1 indicate parity with BSP; above 1 indicates profit relative to BSP; below 1 indicates lower profit. The exact row/column mapping varies by table (C1 vs C3 vs C5) and by distribution block (Lognormal, Normal, etc.). See corresponding page excerpts for each table.

agentic.final_answer:
- Key contribution
  - Provides a structured, cross-scenario benchmarking of profits relative to BSP across pricing schemes, cost settings, distributions, and five Taste categories (K, UP, CP, PB, MB) using three tables: C1 (zero marginal cost), C3 (positive unequal marginal costs, 0.5), and C5 (zero marginal costs with capacity constraints). See tables C1 (page 7/9), C3 (page 17/19), C5 (page 27/29). 
  - Each table aggregates results for multiple distributions (Normal, Lognormal(+/−), Normal(v+/v−), etc.) and shows how profits relative to BSP vary by scenario. (Cited from the described content with the table references above.)

- What the data show (high-level patterns)
  - Zero marginal costs (C1): profits tend to cluster around 1.0 across distributions and schemes, with occasional deviations (e.g., 0.771, 0.934, 0.999, 1.000; 0.650, 0.911, 0.999, 1.000; 0.707–0.976 blocks). See page 7 and 9. 
  - Positive unequal marginal costs (0.5) (C3): profits exhibit greater dispersion across distributions, with several entries above and below 1.0 (e.g., 0.760, 0.958, 0.971, 1.000; 0.936, 0.984, 0.999, 1.022; Normal(v+/v−) blocks; see page 17 and 19).
  - Capacity constraints (C5): fluctuations are more pronounced, including values above 1.1–1.2 in some blocks and below 0.6–0.7 in others (e.g., 0.698, 0.846, 0.877, 1.000; 0.816, 0.977, 1.000, 1.132; 1.143; see page 27 and 29).

- Representative numbers (illustrative, from the cited tables)
  - C1 (zero marginal costs): 0.771, 0.934, 0.999, 1.000; 0.650, 0.911, 0.999, 1.000; 0.707–0.976 blocks. See page 7 (and continuation on page 9).
  - C3 (0.5 marginal costs): 0.760, 0.958, 0.971, 1.000; 0.936, 0.984, 0.999, 1.022; 0.814, 0.997, 0.998, 1.189. See pages 17–19.
  - C5 (capacity constraints): 0.698, 0.846, 0.877, 1.000; 0.816, 0.977, 1.000, 1.132; 1.143; values span roughly 0.7–1.2. See pages 27–29.

- Reading takeaway
  - Tables report profits relative to BSP by scenario/taste and distribution; values near 1 indicate parity with BSP, above 1 indicate profit relative to BSP, and below 1 indicate lower profit. (Refer to the table structures and pages noted above for the exact mappings.)

report_questions.question: What is the main research question of the paper?
report_questions.answer: The main research question is how bundle-size pricing can identify and estimate the demand for bundled plays, including how price sensitivity, taste correlations (covariances), theater-lover propensity, and market size can be identified from observed bundle choices and prices.
report_questions.evidence_type: Inferred from the identification-focused discussion in the Web Appendix.

citation_anchors.note: Discusses how variation identifies each parameter of the demand model (Σ, α).
α is identified by price variation across bundles; discounted bundle provides exogenous variation.

citation_anchors.section: Supply-side pricing constraints provide identification of the market size
citation_anchors.note: Identification of market size M via optimal pricing constraints.

report_questions.quote_snippet: What variation in the data serves to identify each parameter of the demand model?

report_questions.question: What is the paper's primary contribution relative to the existing literature?
report_questions.answer: The paper's primary contribution is to show that bundle-size pricing can approximate mixed bundling and, using exogenous bundle discounts and price variation, identify the underlying demand system (including variances, covariances, price sensitivity α, and market size M) from TheatreWorks data.

citation_anchors.note: Paper title highlights bundle-size pricing as an approximation to mixed bundling.
Discusses identification of the demand system and how variance and covariance terms are identified via bundle choices.
α (price sensitivity) identified by variation in per-play prices across bundles; discounts help identify demand response.
Supply-side pricing constraints identify the market size M.

report_questions.quote_snippet: Bundle-Size Pricing as an Approximation to Mixed Bundling
report_questions.assumption_notes: Assumes no bundle-specific error terms; exogenous variation from discounts and pricing; price variation identifies α and M; assumes no unobserved competition affecting prices beyond model specification.

report_questions.question: What is the central hypothesis being tested?
report_questions.answer: Optimal prices depend on the price-sensitivity parameter α but not on the market size M.

citation_anchors.note: Key claim that optimal prices depend on α but not M.

report_questions.quote_snippet: Importantly, optimal prices depend on α but not M.

report_questions.question: What are the main outcomes of interest (dependent variables)?
report_questions.answer: Profits, specifically profits relative to BSP profits (i.e., profits measured as a ratio to BSP profits).

report_questions.question: What are the key treatment/exposure variables (independent variables)?
report_questions.answer: Key treatment/exposure variables are bundle size (number of plays in a bundle), per-play price variations across bundles, and the discount status (whether a bundle is offered at a discount). These identify price sensitivity (α) in the demand model.
report_questions.evidence_type: Textual evidence from the paper describing identification of price sensitivity via bundle-based price variation and discounts

citation_anchors.note: α identification via price variation across bundles and discounts for larger bundles
discounted 3-play bundle vs non-discounted; price variation identifies α

report_questions.quote_snippet: The degree of price sensitivity, α, is identified by variation in per-play prices across bundles. Because TheatreWorks’ pricing involves discounts for larger bundles

report_questions.question: What setting/context does the paper study (country, market, period)?
report_questions.answer: The paper studies a local theater market centered on TheatreWorks in Palo Alto and Mountain View; the country and exact time period are not specified in the provided text.

citation_anchors.note: Mentions Palo Alto and Mountain View populations, indicating a local theater market setting.

report_questions.quote_snippet: the combined adult populations of Palo Alto and Mountain View

report_questions.question: What is the main mechanism proposed by the authors?
report_questions.answer: Bundle-size pricing with discounts for larger bundles (i.e., pricing that encourages buying larger bundles) as an approximation to mixed bundling.

citation_anchors.note: Describes bundle-size pricing with discounts for larger bundles and its role in identifying price sensitivity.

report_questions.quote_snippet: The degree of price sensitivity, α, is identified by variation in per-play prices across bundles. Because TheatreWorks’ pricing involves discounts for larger bundles

report_questions.question: What alternative mechanisms are discussed?
report_questions.answer: Covariance in tastes (nonzero covariances in the taste covariance matrix Σ) is discussed as an alternative mechanism to explain differences in play shares, alongside variance terms that explain popularity among single-ticket buyers.

citation_anchors.note: Alternative mechanism: covariance in tastes explains differences in play shares.

report_questions.quote_snippet: In other words, allowing for covariance in tastes gives us the flexibility to explain differences in play shares between single-play buyers and multi-play buyers.

report_questions.question: What are the main policy implications claimed by the paper?
report_questions.answer: The paper argues that supply-side pricing constraints enable identification of market size and demand moments using exogenous price variation (such as a discounted bundle), which yields reasonable predicted prices and mitigates endogeneity. This implies policy/pricing implications: leverage exogenous variation to identify market size and calibrate prices, and account for differences across buyer types via the model’s covariance structure.
report_questions.evidence_type: Identification strategy and policy implications of pricing model

citation_anchors.note: Discounted bundle used as exogenous variation to identify demand parameters.
Supply-side pricing constraints identify market size and enable fitting demand moments.
Assumes no bundle-specific error terms; endogeneity concerns addressed by model.

report_questions.quote_snippet: The fact that this specific bundle is offered at a discount is exogenous variation for our purposes.
report_questions.assumption_notes: No bundle-specific error terms; no unobserved competition; price sensitivity identified via supply-side constraints.

report_questions.question: What is the welfare interpretation (if any) of the results?
report_questions.answer: There is no explicit welfare interpretation provided in the available context. The tables report profits relative to BSP under various taste/price schemes (e.g., 'Profits relative to BSP'), but they do not present or discuss welfare metrics (consumer surplus, total welfare, etc.). Any welfare implications would require additional welfare measures not shown here.
report_questions.evidence_type: textual evidence from tables indicating profit measures relative to BSP without welfare analysis

citation_anchors.note: Shows 'Profits relative to BSP' as the metric; no welfare interpretation.

report_questions.quote_snippet: Table C1, continued. Profits relative to BSP, zero marginal costs

report_questions.question: What are the main limitations acknowledged by the authors?
report_questions.answer: Potential price endogeneity with unobserved demand shifters (addressed by integrating over unobserved components, but endogeneity could arise if bundle-specific errors vary by bundle size), the assumption of no unobserved competition (which would bias price sensitivity and market size), and the identification limitation that α and M are not identifiable from demand moments alone without rich variation (requiring supply-side constraints and functional-form assumptions; plus an implicit assumption of no complementarities between the plays).

citation_anchors.note: Standard concern about prices correlated with unobserved demand shifters; authors note integration over unobserved components and possible bundle-specific errors.
α and M are not separately identified from demand moments alone; identification relies on functional form and variation.
Assumes no unobserved competition; violation would bias price sensitivity and market size.

report_questions.quote_snippet: A standard concern with demand estimation is the possibility that observed prices are correlated with unobserved demand shifters.
report_questions.assumption_notes: Assumed no bundle-specific error terms; assumed no unobserved competition; assumed no demand complementarities between plays; identification relies on functional form and supply-side constraints.

report_questions.question: What does the paper claim is novel about its data or identification?
report_questions.answer: The paper claims novelty in identifying covariance terms in tastes (Σ) using bundle-choice data—specifically, that covariance terms are identified by the bundle combinations chosen by multi‑play buyers (e.g., pick-5 subscribers).

citation_anchors.note: Statement that covariance terms are identified by bundle choices of multi-play buyers (e.g., pick-5 subscribers).

report_questions.quote_snippet: The covariance terms themselves are identified by the bundle combinations chosen by multi-play buyers, such as the pick-5 subscribers.
report_questions.assumption_notes: Assumes no bundle-specific error terms and exogenous variation from the discounted 3-play bundle; supply-side pricing constraints identify market size.

report_questions.question: What is the identification strategy (in one sentence)?
report_questions.answer: The identification strategy is to use variation in prices across bundles to identify price sensitivity (α), and to use bundle-choice and market-share variation to identify the variance and covariance parameters of tastes (Σ), with supply-side pricing constraints identifying the market size M.

covariance terms identified by bundle combinations (multi-play buyers)

report_questions.question: What is the estimating equation / baseline regression specification?
report_questions.answer: Baseline estimating equation: estimate demand moments by matching observed market shares of bundle combinations to model-implied shares as a function of tastes (covariances across plays) and prices, using exogenous variation from the discounted 3-play bundle to identify key parameters (θ̄ and λ), and employing supply-side pricing constraints to identify the market size M. The estimation integrates over all unobserved demand components so the error term is not correlated with observed prices.

citation_anchors.note: Mentions integration over unobserved demand components and exogenous variation from the discounted bundle.
Specifies exogenous variation from the discounted bundle as part of identification.
States supply-side pricing constraints provide identification of market size (M) and fitting of demand moments.
Notes there is no remaining error term correlated with observed prices.
Addresses identification of θ̄ and λ (relationship between bundle size and market share).

report_questions.quote_snippet: The fact that this specific bundle is offered at a discount is exogenous variation for our purposes.
report_questions.assumption_notes: Assumes no bundle-specific error terms; integrates over unobserved demand components to avoid correlation between prices and the error term; endogeneity addressed via exogenous discount variation and supply-side constraints.

report_questions.quote_snippet: 2 Additional tables based on numerical experiments Tables C1 through C5 report additional statistics

report_questions.question: What is the key identifying assumption (parallel trends, exclusion restriction, ignorability)?
report_questions.answer: The key identifying assumption is ignorability/exogeneity of the discounted bundle: there are no bundle-specific error terms and the discount is exogenous variation uncorrelated with unobserved demand components.

citation_anchors.note: The discounted bundle is exogenous variation; no bundle-specific error terms; endogeneity concerns addressed by integrating over unobserved demand components.

report_questions.quote_snippet: The fact that this specific bundle is offered at a discount is exogenous variation for our purposes. Stated differently, we assume there are no bundle-specific error terms.
report_questions.assumption_notes: Assumes no bundle-specific error terms; unobserved demand components are integrated out so observed prices are not correlated with unobserved demand shifters.

report_questions.question: What evidence is provided to support the identifying assumption?
report_questions.answer: The evidence cited is the exogenous variation created by discounting a specific 3-play bundle, which provides variation in prices that identifies demand responses, and the claim that there are no bundle-specific error terms (so endogeneity is mitigated). This supports identifying α (price sensitivity) and the related parameters (λ, θ̄) using bundle-level variation, while allowing the supply-side constraints to identify market size M.
report_questions.evidence_type: Exogenous pricing variation (discounted bundle) used to identify demand parameters; assertion of no bundle-specific error terms supporting identification assumptions.

citation_anchors.note: The discounted 3-play bundle provides exogenous variation; no bundle-specific error terms.

report_questions.question: How is the key outcome measured? Any transformations (logs, z-scores, indices)?
report_questions.answer: The key outcome is profits relative to BSP, measured as a relative profit value (a ratio of profits to BSP). The tables present this outcome under different pricing/taste schemes and marginal-cost configurations, and they also display transformations such as Normal, Lognormal, Exponential, and Logit (i.e., profits relative to BSP after applying these transformations).

report_questions.question: How is treatment/exposure measured? Any constructed variables?
report_questions.answer: Treatment/exposure is measured via exogenous variation from a discounted 3-play bundle, which serves as the treatment; constructed variables include variances/covariances of tastes, mean taste and correlation parameters, and the market size estimate M.

citation_anchors.note: Discounted 3-play bundle provides exogenous variation to identify price sensitivity; one bundle is discounted (36.20 per play) while others are not (40.80 per play).
Variance terms Σ(k,k) identified by relative market shares; covariances identified by bundle combinations consumers choose to bundle.
The estimated market size M is 36,055; discusses no unobserved competition assumption.

report_questions.quote_snippet: one specific 3-play bundle is offered at a discount ($36.20 per play) while all other 3-play combinations have no discount ($40.80 per play).
report_questions.assumption_notes: Assumes there are no bundle-specific error terms and that the discount bundle provides exogenous variation for identifying price sensitivity; also assumes no unobserved competition affecting prices.

report_questions.question: Are there key covariates/controls? Which ones are always included?
report_questions.answer: Yes. The model uses key covariates/controls: (i) the qualities of the plays, and (ii) the tendency of consumers to bundle these particular plays together. These controls are explicitly used to identify the variances/covariances of the taste distribution and are thus included in estimation.

report_questions.quote_snippet: the variances and covariances of the taste distribution—i.e., we control for the qualities of these plays, and we control for the tendency of consumers to want to bundle these particular plays together.

report_questions.answer: Normal(+) is the preferred specification because it yields profits relative to BSP near 1 and remains robust across zero, positive, and unequal marginal costs as well as capacity constraints.

report_questions.question: How economically meaningful is the effect (percent change, elasticity, dollars)?
report_questions.answer: The economically meaningful effect is presented as relative changes in profits rather than absolute dollars or elasticity. Profits are reported as a ratio to BSP profits, with 1.0 serving as the baseline; the tables show the 1st, 50th, and 99th percentiles of these profit ratios across pricing schemes and product counts. This yields percent-change interpretations (multipliers) like roughly 0.6–1.3 in the examples, indicating how profitability relative to BSP shifts under different assumptions rather than providing explicit dollar or elasticity measures.

report_questions.question: What are the key robustness checks and do results survive them?
report_questions.answer: Key robustness checks are performed by (i) varying the cost structure (zero marginal costs; positive equal marginal costs; positive unequal marginal costs with levels 0.5 and 0.8) and (ii) testing alternative taste distributions (Normal, Lognormal with positive/negative skew, and other variants) across pricing schemes. Across these robustness checks, profits relative to BSP largely stay around 1 (with many values near 0.9–1.0 and only some extreme cases dipping further), indicating the main results survive the robustness tests.
report_questions.evidence_type: Numerical robustness checks using Tables C1–C4 across cost assumptions and taste distributions.

report_questions.question: What mechanism tests are performed and what do they imply?
report_questions.answer: The mechanism tests focus on identification and endogeneity of pricing in the bundle setting. They check that (1) variance/covariance terms of tastes are identified via bundle choices (e.g., pick-5 subscribers) and that pricing variation (price sensitivity) is identifiable from bundle discounts; (2) there is exogenous variation from the discounted 3-play bundle and no bundle-specific error terms, addressing potential endogeneity between observed prices and unobserved demand shifters; and (3) the model’s identification of θ̄ and λ is explored by considering special cases (e.g., θ̄ = 0) to see how bundle size relates to market share given taste correlations. Together, these tests imply that price sensitivity can be identified from bundle-price variation, the discount bundle provides exogenous variation, and endogeneity is unlikely unless bundle-specific errors correlate with bundle size.
report_questions.evidence_type: Identification and endogeneity mechanism tests in the web appendix of the paper.

citation_anchors.note: Discusses identification of variances/covariances via bundle choices (e.g., pick-5 subscribers) and the role of relative market shares.
Describes endogeneity concerns, exogenous variation from discounted bundle, absence of bundle-specific errors, and identification of price sensitivity (α) and the θ̄/λ components.

report_questions.quote_snippet: The fact that this specific bundle is offered at a discount is exogenous variation for our purposes. Stated differently, we assume there are no bundle-specific error terms.
report_questions.assumption_notes: Assumes no bundle-specific error terms; endogeneity is only a concern if bundle-specific errors vary systematically by bundle size, since TheatreWorks’ prices depend only on total number of plays (except for one 3-play bundle).

report_questions.question: How sensitive are results to alternative samples/bandwidths/controls?
report_questions.answer: Results are sensitive to alternative samples and modeling choices. Across Tables C1–C4, profits relative to BSP vary when changing distribution assumptions (Normal, Lognormal), marginal-cost structures (zero, 0.5, 0.8; and unequal vs. equal), and taste/pricing schemes, indicating robustness checks yield different magnitudes and sometimes directions of effects.
report_questions.evidence_type: Robustness/sensitivity analysis across alternative samples and cost/distribution assumptions (Tables C1–C4)

report_questions.question: How might the results change in different time periods or markets?
report_questions.answer: In different time periods or markets, the results may shift because the model’s key drivers—taste correlations, market size (M), and price sensitivity (α)—can vary across contexts. If tastes are more positively correlated or if the market size is smaller or larger, predicted optimal prices and market shares change; the rank-ordering of play popularity can differ between subscriber groups (e.g., non-subscribers vs subscribers); and the relative profitability under alternative pricing schemes (Normal, Logit, Exponential, etc.) can change because profits depend on the underlying distribution of tastes and marginal costs. Overall, α and M would not be fixed across periods/markets, affecting predicted prices, shares, and which pricing prescriptions perform best.
report_questions.evidence_type: theoretical/model-based explanation grounded in the provided text

report_questions.quote_snippet: we integrate over all unobserved demand components.

report_questions.question: What measurement error risks are acknowledged or likely?
report_questions.answer: Unobserved competition introduces measurement error risk by biasing price-sensitivity estimates and the implied market size. If competition-conditions are not observed, price sensitivity is overestimated, which inflates the estimated market size. The authors also flag that α and M are not separately identified from demand moments, highlighting identification-related measurement risk from the model.
report_questions.evidence_type: identification and measurement error risk due to unobserved competition and moment-based identification

citation_anchors.note: α and M are not separately identified from demand moments; assumption of no unobserved competition affects price sensitivity and market size.

citation_anchors.section: Impact of unobserved competition on estimates
citation_anchors.note: Overestimation of price sensitivity would lead to upward bias in the estimated market size.

report_questions.quote_snippet: We assume the firm faces no unobserved competition, which in theory would lead us to over-estimate con- sumers’ price sensitivity (because our model attributes any competition-induced depression in prices to higher consumer price-sensitivity). In turn, overestimating price sensitivity would lead to an upward bias in the estimated market size.
report_questions.assumption_notes: Assumes no unobserved competition; α and M are not separately identified from demand moments; model relies on functional form for identification.

report_questions.question: What policy counterfactuals are considered or implied?
report_questions.answer: Two policy-relevant counterfactuals are implied: (1) altering market size M (the pool of potential consumers) via the model’s optimal-pricing constraint to see how prices and shares would change; and (2) changing the bundle discount (the discounted 3-play bundle) to assess how demand and bundle shares would respond if that exogenous variation were removed or modified.

report_questions.question: What are the main welfare tradeoffs or distributional impacts discussed?
report_questions.answer: Main welfare tradeoffs are distributional: different taste-pricing schemes with positive, unequal marginal costs yield varying profit outcomes across groups (K, UP, CP, PB, MB). Some schemes raise profits for certain groups relative to BSP while lowering them for others, indicating redistribution across populations and non-uniform welfare gains depending on the pricing scheme and the level of marginal-cost asymmetry (0.5 vs 0.8).

report_questions.question: How sensitive are results to alternative specifications or estimators?
report_questions.answer: Results show some sensitivity to alternative specifications, evidenced by numerical experiments across different taste distributions and cost settings (Tables C2–C4). While profits vary with these specifications, small perturbations in α and M are unlikely to dramatically change the relative profitability of pricing schemes; moreover, α and M are not identified from demand moments alone, though they are claimed to be separately identified from demand moments under functional form. Overall, conclusions about pricing performance depend on the specification, but qualitative comparisons across pricing schemes remain relatively robust to minor parameter shifts.

citation_anchors.section: Sensitivity to α and M perturbations
citation_anchors.note: small perturbations in α and M are unlikely to have dramatic effects on the relative profitability of different pricing schemes
α and M are not separately identified from demand moments alone; formally identified from demand moments under functional form
Tables C2 report profits relative to BSP across taste distributions and cost settings, illustrating sensitivity to specification
Table C3 shows profits under positive and unequal marginal costs (0.5) across distributions, indicating specification sensitivity
Table C4 shows profits under unequal marginal costs (0.8) across distributions, further demonstrating sensitivity to specification

report_questions.quote_snippet: small perturbations in the values of α and M —in contrast to the parameters determining the joint distribution of gross valuations for plays—are unlikely to have dramatic effects on the relative profitability of different pricing schemes.
report_questions.assumption_notes: Assumes no unobserved competition; notes that α and M identification relies on functional form; separate identification from demand moments is discussed but depends on model specification

report_questions.question: ResponseTextConfig(format=ResponseFormatText(type='text'), verbosity='medium')
report_questions.answer:
- What the context provides
  - A set of tables (C1, C3, C5) reporting profits relative to BSP under various pricing schemes and cost scenarios, across five “Taste” categories (K, UP, CP, PB, MB) and multiple distributions (Normal, Lognormal(+/-), Normal(v+/v-), etc.). C1 covers zero marginal costs; C3 covers positive but unequal marginal costs (0.5); C5 covers zero marginal costs with capacity constraints. Citations: Table C1 entries (page 7, words 0–178; continuation page 9, 0–178), Table C3 entries (page 17, 0–181; continuation page 19, 0–181), Table C5 entries (page 27, 0–181; continuation page 29, 0–181). 
  - The tables include explicit examples like Lognormal(+), Lognormal(-), Normal, Normal(v+), Normal(v-), and Normal(+/-) across different rows/scenarios.

- What to take away (high level)
  - Under zero marginal costs (Table C1), many profits cluster around 1.0 for several distributions/schemes, with some deviations (e.g., values like 0.771, 0.934, 0.999, 1.000; 0.650, 0.911, 0.999, 1.000 in early rows). See page 7 and page 9 excerpts. 
  - Under positive unequal marginal costs (0.5) (Table C3), profits show greater variation across distributions (e.g., Lognormal(+), Lognormal(-), Normal, Normal(v+/v-)), with several entries above and below 1.0 (e.g., 0.760, 0.958, 0.971, 1.000; Normal(v+) blocks; Normal(v-) blocks). See page 17 and page 19 excerpts.
  - With capacity constraints (Table C5), there are more pronounced fluctuations, including some values exceeding 1.1–1.2 in places (e.g., Lognormal(+/-) and Normal blocks), and other values below 0.6–0.7 depending on the scenario. See page 27 and page 29 excerpts.

- Representative numbers (illustrative)
  - Zero marginal costs (C1): examples include 0.771, 0.934, 0.999, 1.000; 0.650, 0.911, 0.999, 1.000; 0.707–0.976 blocks in Lognormal/Normal sections. See page 7 (and continuation on page 9).
  - Positive marginal costs (0.5) (C3): examples include 0.760, 0.958, 0.971, 1.000; 0.936, 0.984, 0.999, 1.022 in Lognormal(+); 0.814, 0.997, 0.998, 1.189 in Lognormal(-); Normal blocks around 0.968–1.093. See pages 17–19.
  - Capacity constraints (C5): examples include 0.698, 0.846, 0.877, 1.000; 0.816, 0.977, 1.000, 1.132 (Lognormal(-)); 1.143 in Normal block; values around 0.7–1.2 across the table. See pages 27–29.

- How to read (brief)
  - Tables list profits relative to BSP by scenario/taste and distribution, across several pricing schemes. Values near 1 indicate parity with BSP; above 1 indicates profit relative to BSP; below 1 indicates lower profit. The exact row/column mapping varies by table (C1 vs C3 vs C5) and by distribution block (Lognormal, Normal, etc.). See corresponding page excerpts for each table.
